Iran and Saudi Arabia have always had and will continue to have overlapping interests with respect to a number of issues but that more or less becomes irrelevant when the enmity between two countries runs this deep.
Rouhani's government has tried to reach out to the Saudis in many ways, both publicly and behind the scenes, but there have been very few public, high-level meetings and there would have be plenty of buildup (many off-the-record meetings at lower levels, then perhaps some influential statesmen meeting behind scenes, then low-level diplomats/oil experts, then higher level diplomats and so on) before Rouhani and Salman would ever dream of meeting each other. If this were to ever happen, it would takes years to arrive at.
The key problem here will continue be the perception that the ME must go this way or that...that is, the ME must be remade through the Iranian or Saudi perspective. Key players on both sides, particularly the Saudis, perceive the relationship between the countries as a zero-sum game;  a mentality which precludes mutual benefit through cooperation.

2 things barring my forecast from 0%:
1)  In March 2007 President Ahmadinejad of Iran visited Riyadh and was greeted at the airport by King Abdullah, and the two countries were referred to in the press as "brotherly nations". 
2) Passage of time

After Saudi Arabia's decision to cut diplomatic ties with Iran, and considering Rouhani's domestic concerns over looking 'soft' towards such a powerful and historically significant regional adversary (one that recently cracked down on Shia activists via execution by the dozens), it is unlikely that he would be willing to stage a public meeting with King Saud. However, recent attempts by Pakistan to diffuse tensions between the two nations have reported to show both sides are not willing to further escalate potential conflict. This could, over time, lead to direct talks between the two leaders. It should be noted, the last time diplomatic ties were cut between Iran and the Saudis, it took 2-3 years to reinstate those ties. Regional developments can change this situation quickly, but for now, I am very skeptical that a public meeting at such a high level of governance is likely.

With Hajj disaster and execution of al-Nimr, Iran views King Salman as incompetent and insecure. Iran's sanctions being lifted, and the deputy prince Muhammad bin Salman's boy crush for the US (http://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21685467-muhammad-bin-salman-gambles-intervention-abroad-and-radical-economic-change-home), I think King Al Saud has to consider meeting with President Rouhani. I'll give the slight edge right now for them to meet and watch as this develops.

Some observations:
Iran's re-entry into the world oil market complicates things for Saudi Arabia Both are members of OPEC but, until now, SA has been calling the shots on production quotas. 
Iran's infrastructure is decayed, increasing its lifting costs. SA has very low lifting costs and a modern infrastructure. SA fights these production wars by flooding the market until the other guy goes broke. They might win such a contest with Iran. SA has more or less broken Venezuela that way.
Iran's primary source of hard currency is oil. After sanctions are lifted, several western nations will want to increase trade with Iran, so they will also want Iran to have a source of hard currency. This makes them economic allies of Iran against SA. 
Russia has its own oil issues, but China is in a position to make rapid improvements in Iranian fields in return for status as a long-term preferred buyer. 
Rouhani has spent a lot of political capital on the P5+1 nuclear deal. Hardliners likely won't want him talking to ideological opponent like SA and he may not have enough political capital left to do it anyway.
Hardliners might be more receptive to foreign direct investment, say from China, than to production quota negotiations with SA. 
I wonder if this could mean the beginning of the end of OPEC?

Unless relations take a dramatic turn for the worse, a Salman-Rouhani meeting will very likely (90%) happen before Rouhani's term expires in August 2017.   (An Abdullah-Ahmadinejad meeting took place in 2007 despite the ongoing proxy war). September 1, 2016 is a little past the halfway mark between now and the end of his term. So, a 40%-60% forecast sounds right to me.

Given the Saudi's actions at last November's OPEC (controlled by Saudi Arabia) meeting -- not to cut production to intentionally drive prices down, hurting the Iranian oil market since they do not have the reserves the Saudis have & now, the turn of events with the Iranian nuclear deal allowing Iranian oil exports again, making the Iranians far less dependent on the Saudis,  I can't imagine that either side would be interested in a meeting anytime within the next year.

While there are some potential areas for co-operations (oil, ISIS, etc.), I suspect that much of the engagement between the two powers will occur at a more junior level (if at all). There just doesn't seem to be clear benefit to either Rouhani or Salman to a meeting.
